title: deep clean home clothes stop spread coronavirus
story: And while washing your hands remains the most effective method, there are other steps we can all take to reduce the risk of the deadly bug spreading further.In particular, with scientists revealing that coronavirus can live on surfaces for nine days, its important people deep-clean their homes and clothes to fend off the highly contagious virus.And with the UK currently on lockdown and people cooped up inside, theres no reason you shouldnt be keeping up good home hygiene habits to stay healthy and prevent the spread of deadly Covid-.Here, we take you through exactly how you should be deep cleaning your home and clothes to stop coronavirus in its tracks...Researchers at the US Centers for Disease Control and Prevention found that coronavirus can survive on some inanimate surfaces like bed frames, door handles and kitchen cabinets for up to nine days – suggesting that thorough, regular cleaning is essential.Alexa Mieses, an assistant professor in the department of family medicine at the University of North Carolina, said people should be cleaning and disinfecting their houses regularly.When it comes to cleaning, she told the Huffington Post: You should be doing a regular cleaning routine, which includes removing dirt and dust, and regular household cleaning products are fine for this.But when it comes to disinfecting surfaces, Prof Mieses urges people to use bleach or a cleaner with  per cent alcohol.How often you should disinfect depends on whether you are in the high-risk category for Covid-, how many people live in your home, and how often you all share common items and surfaces.Though there’s no hard and fast rule, you should probably disinfect more frequentlyyou’re high-risk or have a family member working outside the home.If someone in your home is experiencing coronavirus symptoms, you will also want to disinfect surfaces more.You probably don’t need to clean your whole house from top to bottom every day, but rather focus on surfaces including doorknobs, tables, sinks, light switches, remote controls, toilets and handles - anything that is touched often.To follow us on Facebook, simply Like our Coronavirus page.Get Britains best-selling newspaper delivered to your smartphone or tablet each day - find out more.Another thing you can also do to keep your home clean amid the coronavirus pandemic is to make sure you air out the spaces you are spending time in regularly.An infected person will produce thousands of tiny droplets which contain the virus every time they cough and coronavirus can survive in the air for up to three hours.So by opening the window, you can remove and disperse the droplets and reduce the amount of virus in the air – which will reduce the risk of infection for others.There are four key products you should be using to eliminate traces of coronavirus in your home:Soap and water are your first line of defence to remove the virus from surfaces.Soap interferes with the fats in the virus shell and lt the virus from surfaces and this is then rinsed off by water.Of course, you also need to wash your hands when you come in from the shops and wash your food as normal.The active ingredient in bleach – sodium hypochlorite – is very effective at killing the virus.Make sure you leave the bleach to work for ten to  minutes then give the surface a wipe with a clean cloth.The bleach works by destroying the protein and what’s known as the ribonucleic acidof the virus – this is the substance that gives the blueprint for making more virus particles when you become infected.Surgical spirit is mostly made up of the alcohol ethanol which has been shown to kill coronaviruses in as little as  seconds.Like bleach, the alcohol destroys the protein and RNA that the virus is made up of.Moisten a cloth with some neat surgical spirit and rub it over a surface. This will evaporate and you will not need to wipe it off.The active ingredient in surface wipes in an antiseptic - usually benzalkonium chloride.The wipes work by physically removing germs through the pressure you apply when you use them, and the germs then attach to the wipe.They also leave a layer of the antiseptic on the surface that works to kill germs.The antiseptic is shown to work well on bacteria as well as on coronaviruses that infect mice and dogs – but so far, there is no evidence that antiseptics can kill human coronaviruses.Its important to remember your clothes and towels can be a hot-bed for germs, especiallytheyre used by more than one person.This is why its key you wash your clothes more than you usually would during the coronavirus outbreak.In particular, the higher the temperature you wash your clothes in - the more likely you are to kill of any signs of Covid-.And the much revered  degree wash wont necessarily be enough to kill the virus.Laundryheap CEO Deyan Dimitrov says: Our core body temperature runs at an average of C, and provides the ideal conditions for bacteria and viruses to thrive.This meansyou’re looking to fight off the dreaded coronavirus, the much revered C wash might not always pack the punch needed.“Most viruses won’t survive in temperatures over C, so you could opt for this setting items that are particularly germ ridden and washed less often, like tea towels, bedding, bath towels, gloves, scarves, and children’s clothing.However,you’re concerned about your environmental impact by washing clothes at a high temperature, just make sure youre washing clothes far more often instead.You also need to make sure you get the formula right while washing your clothes during coronavirus lockdown - as using extra detergent can be counter-productive.Deyan says: Too much detergent will create extra soap suds which will cling to your laundry and trap dirt there, rather than lt it away.Instead, opt for the recommended dosage, and when it comes to fabric softener, try giving white vinegar a go instead of chemical alternatives.It’s naturally antibacterial and works wonders at softening and freshening up clothes. Just add ½ a cup to the washing machine drawer during the rinse cycle.The smell will dissipate in the machine but you can add some essential oilsyou’re after added fragrance.If youre sharing a house with someone who is poorly it is key you make sure everything is disinfected quickly and effectively after them.Experts urge people to handle all bedding and clothing with rubber gloves and wash straight away - and to never leave it sitting in a hamper.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: step ladder coronavirus lockdown park
story: SELFISH Brits used a ladder to climb into a closed park during lockdown - next to one of Britains most overrun coronavirus hospitals.The rule-breaking park-goers clambered over the walls to visit the grounds just yards from where doctors and nurses are fighting to save lives.They were snapped breaking into Belle Vue park, Newport, which neighbours the Royal Gwent Hospital.The hospital is at the frontline of the coronavirus outbreak having seen the highest number of infections outside of London.It comes as the latest figures showed , have died in Britain after contracting the killer bug, with a further , being infected.Careworker Janet Watkin pictured the ladder louts from her home opposite the picturesque park.She said: Two used the ladder to climb over the wall.One left with the ladder about ten minutes later then came back and was helped back over.I was incredulous. I cant believe people are risking the lives of others.They must think theyre immune. This is why this virus could go on and on.Janet also pictured a second group of people using the park the following day - taking their skateboards with them and even sharing a bottle of water.The Royal Gwent is the biggest hospital within the Aneurin Bevan Health Board area which has seen  confirmed cases of coronavirus.Intensive care consultant Dr David Hepburn told how he was laid low with the virus after catching it from a colleague at the Royal Gwent.He said: At the moment my team at the Intensive Care Unit are looking after a lot of patients who are critically unwell with coronavirus.Some of them are younger than I am and they are certainly not the frail, elderly people that maybe some of us have been led to believe we would be seeing.They are young, they are fit and they have young families.Dr Hepburn urged the British public to follow the isolation advice.He added: Please, please listen to the advice thats going around at the minute.To follow us on Facebook, simply Like our Coronavirus page.Get Britains best-selling newspaper delivered to your smartphone or tablet each day - find out more.This is a small sacrice for a short period of time and then le will get back to normal again but we have to protect everybody and we have to protect the NHS.Dr Hepburn also revealed that he had been fighting the virus and warned about just how sick this can make you.He said: Id like to tell you that I got coronavirus from heroically looking after some of these patients but actually the reality is much more mundane.I think I probably caught this from contact with colleagues at work or possibly somebody out in the street before any of the coronavirus patients arrived on the intensive care unit.It started off very innocuously. I had a burning sensation in my nose, I lost my sense of taste, I never had a cough and then Ive had a week of feeling absolutely terrible.Aching muscles, aching bones and unable to get out of bed - sleeping between  and  hours a day.Im on the mend now thankfully, I hope but I cant emphasise to you how sick this can make you.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: prince charles coronavirus message
story: PRINCE Charles has told Brits to look forward to better times in a message of hope after battling coronavirus.The royal, , spoke publicly for the first time after spending a week in quarantine having been diagnosed with coronavirus.Charles suffered only mild symptoms but is in an age group classed as at increased risk of severe illness.The future king described the crisis facing the country as unprecedented and praised the extraordinary and selfless NHS heroes.Coronavirus has infected more than , people in the UK and claimed , lives.Speaking from his home at Birkhall, in the Scottish Highlands, Charles said: As a nation, we are faced by a profoundly challenging situation, which we are only too aware threatens the livelihoods, businesses and welfare of millions of our fellow citizens.None of us can say when this will end, but end it will. Until it does, let us all try and live with hope and, with faith in ourselves and each other, look forward to better times to come.The Prince of Wales also urged Brits to look out for their elderly neighbours and relatives after being released from his seven-day isolation.And he called for help for people suffering from isolation and loneliness.Charles said: Having recently gone through the process of contracting this coronavirus – luckily with relatively mild symptoms – I now find myself on the other side of the illness, but still in no less a state of social distance and general isolation.As we are all learning, this is a strange, frustrating and often distressing experience when the presence of family and friends is no longer possible and the normal structures of le are suddenly removed.At such an unprecedented and anxious time in all our lives, my we and I are thinking particularly of all those who have lost their loved ones in such very dficult and abnormal circumstances, and of those having to endure sickness, isolation and loneliness.The Prince also heaped praise on the NHS, who have been battling to help stop the spread of the disease.And he also made much as possible, the spread of this virus, our thoughts and prayers are very much with those marvellous people whose extraordinary skills and utter, selfless devotion to duty and the care of their whatever they can to provide support to those on the front line.To receive The Suns Coronavirus newsletterevery tea time, sign up here.To folow us on Facebook, simply Like our Coronavirus page.Get title: what is national minimum living wage uk
story: Rishi Sunak confirmed the announcement in his spring Budget delivered on Wednesday, March , .Read all the latest Budget updates from our live blogThe National Minimum Wage is currently the amount workers under are entitled to.The first National Minimum Wage was set in  by the Labour government.Before that, no official rate existed although trade unions battled hard to fight their workers corner.The National Minimum Wage was re-branded to the National Living Wage in  for those over .Heres the latest national limits as of April  that are legally binding:In  former Chancellor Sajid Javid announced there would be an increase in the National Minimum Wage from £. to £. an hour.The . per cent rise is double the rate of average annual wage growth and also twice the current rate of inflation, as well as the legal minimum’s biggest cash rise ever since it came into force in .The increase in minimum wage will deliver an extra £ a year into the pockets of almost three million who earn it.Sunak has confirmed the changes will come into effect from April , , and outlined future plans for basic-rate workers.Today, we are also publishing a new remit for the independent low pay commission, Sunak said.By  the national living wage will reach two thirds of median earnings - making it £. an hour.With the increase on April , , these will now stand at:Anyone who thinks they are not getting the National Living Wage or National Minimum Wage should complain to their employer in the first instance.If this does not get anywhere, the next step is to take the complaint to HMRC who will investigate.Those who are self-employed, voluntary workers, company directors and family members who live in the home of the employer and do household chores do not qualy for either rate.There is no dference in pay for those that live in London compared to where.The only discrepancy is for people working in agriculture or horticulture.Workers already employed before October , , are entitled to the pay set under their contract of employment.

title: government refusing close coronavirus loophole
story: NewsGovernment refusing to close coronavirus loophole thats left thousands without cashPeople who started a new job after February  cant get furloughed - but the government is understood to be resisting calls to extend the date because of practical problemsShareCommentsByDan BloomOnline Political Editor:,  APR Updated:,  APR NewsMillions of workers are having % of their wages paid by the state - but there are gaps in the system " to FREE email alerts from Mirror - The Coronavirus BriefingSubscribeWe will use your email address to send you newsletters. Please see ourPrivacy Noticefor more information on how we use your data and your data protection rights.Thank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee ourprivacy noticeInvalid Email The government is refusing to close a loophole in its coronavirus bailout that has left thousands of workers without cash.Any full- or part-time worker can have % of their wage paid by the state, up to £, a month, under a groundbreaking furlough scheme. But the scheme does not apply to people who started a new job after the cut-off date of February . Instead, the only way for them to be furloughed is to be rehired to their previous job and then be put on the scheme. Whether this happens is up to the old employer. This stops well short of demands by thousands of workers who said the date of February  must be extended. The Mirror understands the government is resisting calls to extend the scheme beyond February  because of practical dficulties. To prevent fraud, officials decided to capture peopleaposs earnings in February - the most recent full month - to work out how much they are owed through the scheme. Senior officials are understood to be aware of the loophole, but believe there had to be a cut-off date for the Treasury to snapshot peopleaposs earnings. Officials appear to accept that any cut-off date would have imperfections, but not every business or inidual job in the country can be saved. A Treasury spokesman said: Obviously it’s important to have proof that iniduals are connected to the firms that are furloughing them. Tony MacDonald, , from Dundee, said the decision was so disappointing.  Tony missed the scheme by three days after leaving his job of three years to start a new role as a fire safety engineer. He and we Logan, , have been left high and dry unable to support children Alfie, , and Aoe, , on her midweaposs salary alone. Tony told the Mirror: The new guidelines said your old employer can take you back but mine isnapost budging on that. Theyaposre struggling enough as it is at the moment.

Michael Gove last night announced the first of thousands of new ventilator devices will roll off the production line this weekend, and be delivered to the NHS next week. However, while tens of thousands of ventilators have been ordered, Mr Gove did not clary exactly how many would roll off the production line this weekend. Today the government claried this number is in the region of . Officials insisted potentially hundreds more of the Penlon devices could arrive in the weeks afterwards, with thousands of other ventilators in the coming months. Separately, thousands of ventilators are also being ordered from overseas. It is not confirmed what the progress of these is, but they were due to arrive in stages over the course of weeks and months. The number emerged after the number of coronavirus patients admitted to UK hospitals soared past , for the first time. Britain is racing to buy in , off-the-shelf ventilators from overseas to add to , the NHS already has. On top of this, the government launched a ventilator challenge urging UK firms to produce hastily-designed le-saving devices. The  new ventilators to be delivered next week are part of this challenge - and are the first to be produced and approved for use. They are known as the Penlon ventilator device and have been adapted from existing designs by a consortium of firms, rather than built from scratch. The consortiumaposs leaders include Formula  teams McLaren and Mercedes, Ford, Siemens and Meggitt. Aside from this, Dyson also have an agreement to produce , ventilators for the UK government but theyaposre yet to be approved by regulators.  And a team led by UCL, working with Mercedes Benz, will produce a further , new CPAPdevices to support affected patients. If all the orders are fulfilled, they could be enough to meet the peak demand in the NHS - leaving no Covid- patient without the vital breathing device. But the government has faced criticism for not acting sooner, given many orders will take months to fulfil. Former Tory justice minister Dr Phillip Lee, who later defected to the Lib Dems, said we knew in January that Covid- was dangerous and there was a ventilator capacity problem. I donapost understand how the government didnapost at that point err on the side of caution and start ordering ventilators, he told Sky News. He said there should be , or , sat in a warehouse after an exercise in  showed the capacity wasnapost there. Robert Jenrick, the Communities Secretary, revealed the figure of  ventilators when he was quizzed on ITVaposs Good Morning Britain. He faced claims the UK has not prepared properly to test people for Covid- after aiming for , tests a day, less than Germanyaposs , a week.

Please see ourPrivacy Noticefor more information on how we use your data and your data protection rights.Thank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee ourprivacy noticeInvalid Email A -year-old boy with coronavirus died without family by his side as he became Britainaposs youngest victim of the pandemic.Ismail Mohamed Abdulwahab had no known underlying health conditions and is one of the youngest people in the world to die after contracting Covid-. The teen - whose dad died of cancer, leaving his mum to care for seven children - didnapost have any family with him at the time due to the highly infectious nature of the virus. Ismail, from Brixton, south London, died at Kingaposs College Hospital in the early hours of Monday morning after medics put him on a ventilator and then into an induced coma as they desperately tried to save his le. Have you been affected by coronavirus  Email webnews@mirror. The Mohamed family said: Ismail started showing symptoms and had dficulties breathing and was admitted to Kings College Hospital. He was put on a ventilator and then put into an induced coma but sadly died yesterday [Monday] morning. To our knowledge he had no underlying health conditions. We are beyond devastated.A GoFundMe page set up to cover funeral expenses reached the £, mark on Wednesday morning.The initial fundraising target was £,. Madinah College, which offers Arabic language and Islamic studies courses, set up the page and said the extra money will go directly to the family. It said on Wednesday: The family is overwhelmed and grateful to all the donors and prayers, may Allah bless you and reward you all.  Ismail was admitted to Kingaposs College Hospital last Thursday and tested positive for coronavirus the following day. His mother and six siblings are awaiting the results of a post-mortem which will confirm the cause of death and determine whether he had any pre-existing conditions. Fundraiser and family friend Mark Stephenson, an academic director at Madinah College, where Ismailaposs sister works, said: Ismail was tested positive for Covid-. They have not released the body yet, as the coroner wants to do an autopsy - Iaposm assuming due to his young age and not having underlying conditions.  A message on the GoFundMe page states: It is with great sadness to announce that the younger brother of one of our teachers at Madinah College has sadly passed away this morningdue to being infected with Covid . Ismael [sic] was only  years old without any pre-existing health conditions and sadly he died without any family members close by due to the highly infectious nature of Covid . We at Madinah College would like to appeal to our brothers and sisters to donate generously to help raise £ for the funeral costs and to support the family. May Allah grant the family patience through this dficult time and make it a means of drawing closer to Him.  Ismailaposs death came the same day as that of a -year-old girl in Belgium. She is the youngest person to die in Europe after contracting coronavirus. In recent days, a -year-old boy has died in Portugal and a -year-old girl has died at a hospital in Paris. Luca Di Nicola, , an assistant chef from Nereto, Italy, died at North Middlesex Hospital in Enfield, north London, last Tuesday from apparent fulminant pneumonia. His family said he was very healthy and the NHS confirmed he had no underlying health conditions. For those concerned they have coronavirus in the UK, Public Health England has issued advice about how to self-isolate. . Stay at home: Donapost leave your house except when you need to seek medical care. Ask for help buying groceries or have them delivered. . Stay away from your housemates: Stick in a well-ventilated room away from others, with the door closed. Use a separate bathroom and wear a facemask when it shared areas. . Call ahead before visiting the doctors so they can take extra precautionary measures. . Cover you coughs and sneezes: Make sure to cover your nose and mouth and to throw away disposable tissues in a plastic waste bag. . Wash your hands regularly: This should be done often and thoroughly with soap and water, for at least  seconds, rinse and dry thoroughly. . Avoid sharing household items: You should not share dishes, drinking glasses, cups, eating utensils, towels, bedding or other items with other people in your home when you have used them. After using these items, wash them thoroughly with soap and water. . Do not have visitors in your home. . Keep away from your petspossible.. Keep your clothes clean: Do laundry on the highest temperature possible and clean all surfaces around the washing machine. . Monitor your symptoms: Seek prompt medical attentionyour illness is worsening, for example,you have dficulty breathing, orthe person you are caring for symptoms are worsening. Speaking on Wednesday morning, Housing and Communities Secretary Robert Jenrick said the deaths of a -year-old and a -year-old with coronavirus is a reminder that the disease affects everyone. He told BBC Breakfast: Every death is a tragedy, but two young people dying is even more sobering. It does remind us all that this is a virus thataposs indiscriminate. It doesnapost just affect the elderly, or those who are extremely vulnerable because of their pre-existing conditions, although those people do need to take particular care. It can affect all of us and I think many young people have felt, or some young people have felt, almost invincible, and you saw that in some of the scenes a couple of weeks ago of young people out enjoying themselves when we first started to implement some of the social distancing measures.  I think now everybody in the country understands and appreciates the seriousness of the situation, and is following the medical advice, which is to stay at home, by doing so protect the NHS and help to save lives. A Kingaposs College Hospital spokesperson said of Ismailaposs death: Sadly, a -year old boy who tested positive for Covid- has passed away, and our thoughts and condolences are with the family at this time. The death has been referred to the Coroner and no further comment will be made.” Dr Nathalie MacDermott, NIHR Academic Clinical Lecturer, Kingaposs College London, said: It is very sad to hear of the death of a -year-old infected with Covid-. While we know it is much less likely for children to suffer severe Covid- infection than older adults, this case highlights the importance of us all taking the precautions we can to reduce the spread of infection in the UK and worldwide. title: coronavirus bosch factory denies putting
story: NewsCoronavirus: Bosch factory denies putting workers at risk in lockdown to try to beat rivalsEXCLUSIVE: A factory worker at a Bosch boiler factory in Worcester has accused the company of putting profits before staff health as it looks to avoid falling behind despite the Covid- outbreakShareCommentsByRyan Merrield:,  APR Updated:,  APR NewsWorcester Bosch has been accused of putting workers lives at risk for profits in Covid- lockdown " to FREE email alerts from Mirror - The Coronavirus BriefingSubscribeWe will use your email address to send you newsletters. Please see ourPrivacy Noticefor more information on how we use your data and your data protection rights.Thank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee ourprivacy noticeInvalid EmailBosch has denied putting staff’s health at risk in a desperate bid to get ahead of its rivals during the coronavirus lockdown. Despite government orders for all non-essential business operations to halt during the deadly Covid- outbreak, the boiler firmaposs Worcester branch wants to ensure it doesnapost fall behind. With certain competitor factories having shut their doors for the foreseeable future, the Bosch plant has been telling production staff to continue working, heightening the risk of them catching the virus. There will then be a brief shutdown period for a fortnight from April  in which staff are to use holiday allowance - before ing later in the month in an effort to get a head start on summer production. In an internal email sent to employees - and seen by the- Bosch admitted demand is down and supply of component parts is currently a critical issue for us. And with a subsequent major push going to be needed to make up for the dip, they canapost afford staff to be taking time off later in the year. We cannot leave ourselves in a position when we do get through this, that most of our employees still have a full yearaposs holiday to take in the second half of the year, the email said. We are using a period of shutdown to realign our business in line with this situation, it continued.   This will have an adverse impact on our business. We are committed to ensuring we retain a strong business and our workforce into the longer term.   It said workloads need to be carefully managed through the coming period and asked all Bosch Thermotechnology aposassociatesapos to act responsibly and take two weeks Easter break using paid holidays.  We understand that this is not the ideal time to take holidays but by using a reasonable share of them at this time of the year the business will be better placed once the coronavirus outbreak has abated to ensure a strong ramp up as demand grows once more, the email added.  One factory employee - who did not wish to be named - told thethe holiday allowance has allegedly already been automatically taken to account for those two weeks off. They claimed the email has been translated by production staff to mean weaposve got no demand and canapost get parts, so weaposre taking holiday off you so you canapost use it later in the year when we have parts.  All about profits. Absolute joke, they said. The disgruntled worker went on to claim staff were told to take four holiday days at the start of the year for Christmas shutdown and now this. We get  days holiday a year and half of it has been dictated by the company so that they can have everyone flat out in the summer building to get ahead of Ideal [Boilers], who is our major competitor. Itaposs all theyaposve been worrying about for months. Ideal have shut so theyaposre trying to get ahead.  They continued: Ideal have come up as a big worry for the company in the past few months, as theyaposve gone from nothing to a big competitor. And here we are. Itaposs a joke, shameful of a multi-million [pound] company. They claimed the two metre distance rule is not being enforced on the factory floor while  per cent of managerial support is from home. Itaposs literally the workers building with little support from above.  One apparent Bosch worker took to Twitter to complain the company is still sending field service engineers into peopleaposs homes every day. Referring to the Worcester factory floor staff being forced to take two weeks holiday at Easter, they added: [Theyaposre] not key workers so why are they being forced in  Another person tweeted: Why is Worcester Bosch still making their staff work in this coronavirus outbreak, putting lives at risk  In response, a Bosch spokesperson said it is fully supportive of its staff and has implemented all of the government’s most current guidelines during this constantly changing situation.  The spokesperson said manufacturing is not on the government’s list of businesses that need to close providing the guidance on hygiene, safe distancing etc can be complied with. Referring to engineers entering peopleaposs homes, they said the government has stated this can continue to provide essential repair and maintenance providing they are well and have no symptoms of the virus. They said the Secretary of State for Business, Energy and Industrial Strategyaposs guidelines state thatyou are not specically required to close the workplace then it is important to carry on the business.  However, the spokesperson went on to emphasise while all employees where possible are being asked to work from home, manufacturing and logistic teams need to come to site to carry out their work. They said the company has provided full guidance on hygiene and social distancing for those in vital areas - including the Worcester plant. We have communicated guidelines and implemented our own measures, such as redesigning our factory floors to demonstrate how to maintain appropriate social distancing, although we would like to stress that it is down to inidual employees to adhere to the guidance in line with the government advice.

Please see ourPrivacy Noticefor more information on how we use your data and your data protection rights.Thank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee ourprivacy noticeInvalid EmailOn New Year’s Eve, while most people around the world were thinking of midnight celebrations and the start not just of a new year but a new decade, the World Health Organisation received a worrying notication from the authorities in China. The report stated that aposcases of pneumonia of unknown etiologydetected in Wuhanapos. We now know that concerns had been raised a few weeks earlier in China and that the delays in taking action did not just cost valuable time but also cost lives. Outbreaks of emerging infectious disease are not uncommon. But when they are not dealt with quickly, they can be devastating. What makes Covid- unusual is the way and the speed at which it has spread around the world. Just three months have passed since the alert to the World Health Organisation. It is almost unbelievable to think that not millions or even hundreds of millions of people around the world are now in lock-down - but billions. Entire populations are in isolation, with .billion in India alone forced to stay indoors. Streets are empty – at least of humans. Videos from all over Europe show wild boar, goats and even badgers roaming through town centres asthese were their natural habitats. As well as the stock markets that have collapsed, affecting pensions and savings, mass lay-offs, airlines that may never fly again and more, the mental strains of being cut off from family and friends are not easy to handle – especially alongside the fears of infection. And then of course there are the tragedies of those who have died, whether young and healthy or otherwise - each loss leaves an unfillable gap in the lives of those around them. But there will be brightness at the end of all this when we come out the other side. Learning lessons from the past is one of the reasons why people study history. It is important that we see the positive things that will come about as a result. First, of course, is that the experience of Covid- should mean that we never find ourselves in this position again. Apart from better co-operation and sharing of information between states, we must learn to respond quicker and better than we did when the scale of the problem was already clear. In the UK, we did too little, too late. Our pain will save lives when something like this happens again – which it will. Second, and similarly, the problems the NHS has faced with a lack of ventilators, protective clothing and other supplies will mean that we stockpile and prepare better for the future. It is incredible to see Formula  teams work with universities to invent and start to produce breathing equipment in a matter of days but we need to invest better and more appropriately to be able to deal with crisis in the future.  Third, and comfortingly, hygiene standards in the UKshould improve dramatically. According to a Gallup poll conducted five years ago, only three quarters of Brits wash their hands after using the toilet.

Please see ourPrivacy Noticefor more information on how we use your data and your data protection rights.Thank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee ourprivacy noticeInvalid EmailLoss of sense of smell and taste could be the best way to tell whether you have Covid-, researchers have said. Scientists at Kingaposs College London have been tracking symptoms via their specially-created app. By March , the Covid Symptom Tracker App had more than . million users sign up to log their symptoms, or lack thereof, daily. Some % of the . million people who had signed up by March  and tested positive reported a loss of smell and taste, compared with % of those who tested negative, analysis of the data showed. Researchers said the reports of those symptoms were much stronger in predicting a positive Covid- diagnosis than self-reported fever. The team behind the app has now created a model featuring a combination of symptoms, including loss of smell and taste, fever, persistent cough, fatigue, diarrhoea, abdominal pain and loss of appetite, and said the strongest predictor is loss of smell and taste. Commonly accepted symptoms of the respiratory disease include a fever, which NHS England says is usually a temperature of C or above, tiredness and a dry cough. Under current Government guidance people are advised to self-isolatethey have a new continuous cough and or high temperature. The World Health Organisationsays other symptoms can include shortness of breath, aches and pains, and a sore throat.  Some people have also reported a loss of taste and or smell, as well as abdominal pains. Last week the WHOaposs Dr Maria Van Kerkhove said there had been quite a few reports about people in the early stages of disease maybe losing sense of smell or taste. But she added this is something that we need to look in to, to really capture to see whether this is one of the signs of Covid-. We are building a map of appreciation for the NHS heroes looking after us through the coronavirus crisis. Place your heart on our live updating map at www.thanksamillionnhs. Add your partial postcodeto put a heart on the map and you can add a thank you message too. If youaposre an NHS worker, youaposll also find a handy list of all the places and brands currently offering you well-deserved discounts. Share the page to encourage others to show their support! Lead researcher Professor Tim Spector from Kingaposs College, said: When combined with other symptoms, people with loss of smell and taste appear to be three times more likely to have contracted Covid- according to our data. And should therefore self-isolate for seven days to reduce the spread of the disease.

Please see ourPrivacy Noticefor more information on how we use your data and your data protection rights.Thank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee ourprivacy noticeInvalid EmailCoronavirus has forced people to socially distance themselves from their nearest and dearest. While all non-esential shops are now closed and bars, pubs cafes and restaurants shut down, people have been urged to make sure they are socially distancing themselves from others. Groups of more than two, unless theyaposre members of your own home, are banned and people are being told to make sure they stay at least six feet from others. In a bid to slow the spread of Covid- people are also being told they can only leave homethey need to get essentials like food or medication, or for exercise once a day. It also means thousands of birthday parties for little ones have had to be cancelled. But former Disney princess Megan-Leigh Boatman is bringing joy to countless children by entertaining them over FaceTime.The -year-old from Basildon, Essex, was spurred into action when she saw a Facebook post by a heartbroken mother whose little girl was devastated because her fourth birthday party had to be cancelled.The beautician, who gave up her job as an entertainer due to ill health, wanted to help cheer them up so is offering to bring some magic to children’s special days during Covid- home isolation. Megan-Leigh wrote a post on Facebook to parents to explain what she was offering and itaposs now been shared more than , times, with more than  FaceTime calls booked in. She explained: With everything going on in the world right now, I’ve decided to dust off my tiara and do what I love most. Being a princess and making children smile. Tonight I see a mumaposs plea for a princess to FaceTime her daughter on her birthday. This little girl has had to cancel her birthday party twice because of the recent Covid- virus. I feel so sorry for the little girl but I’m extremely happy I’m able to brighten her birthday on Sunday. It got me thinking about all the other little children missing out on their birthday parties or even children feeling a little low and needing their spirits lted. So, If anyone is in need of a Princess FaceTime please message me as I would love to help as much as I can over the next few weeks months. All I ask for inis a small donation. Megan had previously worked as a Disney princess, where she would entertain children at birthday parties, but she was forced to give up her dream job due to ill health - and instead went to work in the beauty industry.She said: Everyone that knows me knows the last  months have been very hard for me due to ill health. I thought I’d be able to get back to work and a normal pain free le once I had surgery, but it has had to be postponed until things improve in the world. But I’m now able to do something I love from the comfort of my own home without causing too much strain and pain on myself. As running around after  children wasn’t doable, Megan said the fact she can offer this service and still make children happy while safely staying at home is amazing. She added: I’ve found it really tough being unable to work and have had to make a lot of le changing choices along the way. So I’m really excited to be able to run Princess FaceTime from the comfort of my own home.Megan started FaceTime calling and surprising children at the weekend after her post first went viral last Friday. She said one little girl was so impressed by her chat with Cinderella that she sent over a handwritten letter for Megan to respond to. The real-le princess said: Most of the children are talking about having to stay at home so I tell them I also have to stay at home in my castle to keep safe. I called a four-year-old little boy dressed as Elsa from Frozen and now he is going around telling his friends I’m his girlfriend while another little girl told me I am her best friend and she has invited me over for a tea party when the nasty virus has gone. Megan also spoke to a Disney fan who has been poorly with chicken pox and described her as so brave, sweet and loving every minute of her chat with Cinderella. Speaking about how happy her service is making children, Megan said: Their reactions have been amazing. They’ve all been so happy and the smiles on their faces really makes it so rewarding. One little girl showed me all her Lego creations and another askedI have to clean all my castle by myself. I’m really looking forward to the rest of the FaceTimes I’ve got booked in.Glad she is able to put her ‘rewarding’ job back to good use again, Megan said it felt great to put the wigs and costumes back on to do something positive during the coronavirus outbreak.She said: I’m overwhelmed with the reaction it has had. I wasn’t expecting it to spread as well as it has. It’s made me so happy and given me something to focus on during this awful time! I’m glad I can play a tiny part in spreading some happiness around.‘I only thought I’d have a few messages and be able to brighten up a few kidsapos days but, it’s gone crazy. I’m glad a small gesture like this can bring a lot of happiness. In just  hours, Megan had more than  messages about her offer to dress up as Ariel from Little Mermaid, Elsa from Frozen, Cinderella and more - scheduling  video calls over the next few weeks. She added: This will hopefully cheer up so many children. It’ll give them something magical to remember during this crisis. They’ll be able to tell all their family and friends about it and it will hopefully lt their spirits. Megan’s social media page now includes several excited reactions from little girls who were shocked and delighted to chat to their favourite princess.

And while the £ box went down a treat with some, others were less impressed with some of the contents.As well as your kitchen cupboard must-haves, like soup and baked beans, the box also contains a few luxury items such as Percy Pig sweets, shortbread biscuits, salted peanuts and chocolate buttons.According to the Manchester Evening News, shoppers were quick to point out that the sugary products were unnecessary at this time and instead suggested in the MS website review section that the company add in a few healthier items. Basic items would be much more appropriate including things such as long le milk and easy to cook bread. Another said: I was pleased to see this initiative but disappointed with the contents. As other reviewers have said, far to many sweet items and not enough fresh produce or chilled ready meals. A third added: Some good staples, but far too much sugar. Iaposd only order this in an emergency.

The woman, who asked not to be named, headed to an Aldi in Liverpool at .am after finishing a long  hour sht at Alder Hay Childrenaposs Hospital. I had just finished work and the girls had said to me Aldi opens at am and the NHS donapost have to stand in the queue, the nurse, who has  years experience at Alder Hay, said. Professor Maneesh Singh believes his company Biocel Analytics has come up a game-changer that will smash the current  hours or longer people are waiting to seethey have the deadly virus. Competitors from across the fields of science have joined the race in recent weeks to find a solution as the pandemic continues to ravage the world. The new invention makes use of infrared microspectroscopy which can identy and study chemical substancesapos makeup. Patients must give a swab sample taken from inside the mouth before the device creates a unique aposfingerprintapos spectrum representing a positive or negative result. The algorithm that the fingerprintaposs data goes through was developed by Prof Singh and his colleagues in just a week, reports HullLive. Itaposs a robust emerging technique, said the former obstetrician who was born and raised in Hull, Yorkshire. Weaposre not after any profits, itaposs about making a scientic breakthrough. Weaposre in a major crisis. This has been likened to war and war is when tech comes to the forefront and people have to work more rapidly. The government donapost have to take it, but we just want to be in a position to offer a potential solution for their consideration. Prof Singh hopes to send the fingerprint spectrum data via Bluetooth to an app for any mobile device which has the algorithm embedded in it, so the result can be given almost instantly.  He comes from a family of NHS employees, including an anaesthetist brother and GP father - and said any profit from the new product would go into further research. Weaposre here to help our colleagues, really, so we want to develop this as rapidly as possible, continued Prof Singh. The sudden emergence of Covid- meant we believed we could do something to make a dference, so weaposve just gone for it whole-heartedly. We felt we had to give it a shot. Iaposm not the type to sit back in a crisis, I like to take control, so itaposs quite tough to not be as involved as I was in the NHS, but I wanted to try to do something in a dferent way. The field of infrared spectroscopy has been used for a number of years in other areas of medicine, with previous studies showing the method can also be used in the diagnosis of oian cancer and Alzheimeraposs Disease.  That means the infrastructure put in place at a time of war will still be used in a time of peace, he said. Though medical tests normally have to undergo years of rigorous testing and meet strict regulations, the Government has loosened some requirements to allow potential tests and other research into the virus to progress more quickly to meet the speed of the pandemic. Prof Singh said that, with another study to be imminently published in the science journal aposNatureapos and partnership with at least one NHS trust expected to help develop the technology, it could be just days before they have tested enough samples to attest to the accuracy of their method. He said they hope to run the test alongside the typical method currently used to confirm their results. In a study of a thousand samples, weaposll run it alongside the current methods to make sure itaposs accurate, he said. With the regulatory process being sped up,you can prove you have a test that is reliable, which we will be able to do within three or four weeks, within a couple weeks we can be testing patients alongside regular tests.  Professor Francis Martin, Prof Singhaposs supervisor during his PhD at the University of Lancaster  years ago and his long-term mentor, said there had been a great interest in developing the interdisciplinary approach for a number of years. Itaposs using physics to solve a biological problem, and itaposs been used for a number of biological problems before in oncology and neurodegenerative diseases, and in this case virology in the diagnosis of COVID, he said. The good thing about this aposfingerprintapos measurement is that it is numerical data, an objective measurement which can be put into an algorithm. This allows in real time for the sample to be categorised and classied, soyou have developed an algorithm to distinguish between healthy versus infected, then you can saya sample is infected or uninfected. So itaposs a very powerful tool. Having discussed the new test with Prof Singh, Prof Martin noted that a similar test - using a sample of blood rather than saliva - could be used to testsomeone is immune to the disease by seeingthey have developed the antibodies specically produced by the body to fight Covid-.

story: NewsopinionVoice of the Mirror: Be proud of our Armys coronavirus hospital achievementWe should be proud of how Britains armed forces built the ,-bed Nightingale Hospital in London at breakneck speed, beating the impressive ,-bed hospital built in  days in ChinaShareCommentsByVoice of the Mirror:,  MAR NewsopinionMembers of the Queens Ghurka Engineers Regiment helped construct the Nightingale Hospital in London " to FREE email alerts from Mirror - The Coronavirus BriefingSubscribeWe will use your email address to send you newsletters. Please see ourPrivacy Noticefor more information on how we use your data and your data protection rights.Thank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee ourprivacy noticeInvalid EmailOur troops are brilliant The magnicent response of the military in this crisis justies why we boast Britain’s armed forces are the world’s best. Without the Army’s expertise, the emergency ,-bed Nightingale Hospital would never have been created in a London conference centre. Matching facilities are also planned around the country.  When China built a hospital from scratch at breakneck speed, we watched with awe. Now we’ve opened a better one in Britain in a matter of weeks let’s give praise where it’s due. This is a grim war against coronavirus when the death toll soared in a day by a record  to , and shameful shortages of protective clothing gambles with the lives of NHS workers while a goal of , tests a day is postponed until the end of April. But as well as highlighting what is going wrong to pressure an incompetent Tory Government into doing the right thing, we must also laud successes. Our armed forces have risen to the challenge with saved lives the likely result. Thank you. Special workers Let us salute more of the unsung heroes in the battle against deadly coronavirus. We feature some of them today including shopworkers, housing staff and blood centre manager. Then there are the cleaners, carers, refuse collectors, bus and lorry drivers, police, fire, armed forces and food producers.

story: NewsVoice of the Mirror: Supporting journalism now is more important than everUK newspaper publishers - including Reach, the owners of the Daily Mirror - have joined forces to call on advertisers to support UK journalismShareByVoice of the Mirror:,  APR Updated:,  APR News " to FREE email alerts from Mirror - The Coronavirus BriefingSubscribeWe will use your email address to send you newsletters. Please see ourPrivacy Noticefor more information on how we use your data and your data protection rights.Thank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee ourprivacy noticeInvalid EmailThe UK’s newspaper publishers have today joined forces to call on advertisers to support quality journalism during the Covid- crisis.While all news brands have seen a surge in demand from readers for quality, accurate reporting, advertising industry ‘blocklists’ are preventing adverts from appearing alongside online stories about coronavirus. If the pandemic lasts for another three months the total loss to news brands is expected to be £ million. The letter, published today, was written on behalf of the industry by Tracy De Groose, executive chair of Newsworks. It asks advertisers to remove blocklists from trusted UK news brands to ensure they can continue to fund quality British journalism at a time of national crisis.   Here is the letter in full: Dear Advertiser, These are challenging times for all of our businesses no matter the size, sector or region we operate in. However, working together we can help reduce the devastating impact of this virus. We are open and ready to support you, so please let us know how we can best do that for your people, your customers and your business. Across our own industry, our journalists are working harder than ever to ask the right questions and to deliver accurate information in the most helpful and accessible ways possible for their readers. Yet, as the crisis unfolds, the strain on journalist resources and their ability to keep reporting is only going to get tougher.

Please see ourPrivacy Noticefor more information on how we use your data and your data protection rights.Thank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee ourprivacy noticeInvalid EmailA volunteer helping her community through the coronavirus crisis had all four tyres on her car slashed while assisting her neighbours.Helen Crouch, who has been delivering meals, prescriptions and groceries to people in coronavirus isolation in three Leicestershire villages, wept when she realised her car had been damaged.The tyres of Helenaposs VW Touareg were attacked sometime between about pm on Saturday and am on Sunday. The -year-old single mum, who set up the Bagworth and Thornton Coronavirus Community Response Team earlier this month, said: “I am a strong person but I just stood there and cried. “I can’t believe anyone could do this. “There were leaflets advertising the response team in my back windows and everyone has seen me out and about in Thornton, Bagworth and Stanton under Bardon. No other car was damaged. “I think someone has deliberately targeted my car to try to stop me doing what I am doing. It is sick beyond belief. “All four tyres have holes in. It looks like someone has used a big screwdriver to inflict the damage. “My car broke down on Saturday so I had to leave it there. I had just delivered a shepherd’s pie to an old person in the village. “I called a friend and told him about my car breaking down. He said I could borrow his van to carry on my rounds as I had other food to deliver.” Helen, who has visited more than  people in the  days since she set up the volunteer group, worked until the evening on Saturday then went out the next morning. Helen said: As I drove past my car I saw that all four tyres were flat as a pancake. “I got out and I could clearly see the puncture marks in each tyre. That’s when I lost it.” A distraught Helen, a self-employed interior designer who is now jobless, filmed the damage to her tyres. In the footage she can be heard saying: “Do you know what  I’ve done two weeks of response work in these two villages and somebody has stabbed every single one of my tyres on a car that has broken down and that I need. “I hope you are proud of yourselves. £. I have just lost my business. Thanks a lot.” Shortly after the video was posted online, Thornton resident Matt Goddard set up a Gofundme appeal to pay for Helen’s tyres to be replaced.  He set a target of £ which was achieved within two hours. Matt, who is in a -day isolation at home with his we and child, is a firefighter with the Leicestershire Fire and Rescue Service based at Lutterworth. Matt said: “This is terrible. Helen is amazing. “She has been delivering stuff to us and to my parents who are also in isolation in the village. “Any extra money raise will got to help the group carry on their great work looking after people and helping them in isolation.” Helen said she was touched by the response. Helen said: “I can’t thank the people enough. It is very humbling to know that, in these tough times, people have actually donated money to help me out.  “A horrible thing has happened but this just shows that the vast majority of people are good. “I want the person who slashed my tyres to know that I won’t be discouraged or beaten. They won’t win – together the whole community will win.” By pm today, the fund total had reached £,. Leicestershire Police have confirmed they are investigating the tyre slashing.

title: dundee james mcpake sfa spfl
story: The uncertainty around the Scottish game right now is the hardest thing to deal with from a football point of view, according to Dundee boss James McPake.Matches ground to a halt two and a half weeks ago as the seriousness of the coronavirus pandemic became more and more apparent.Government restrictions have grown ever tighter since in an attempt to curb the spread of Covid- with only key workers now allowed to travel into their workplace.With infections continuing to rise, getting back to something approaching normal society looks a distant possibility, and the Scottish football authorities have been reluctant to make any definitive judgments as to how things will proceed in the game.With no real date to work towards for ato playing games, it’s a frustrating time for football managers, though McPake is well aware of the huge problems facing the world.He said: “The dficult thing is the uncertainty.“At the start we were told the games wouldn’t be played the weekend coming so we were still in our heads thinking we had to prepare for Inverness the following week.“We had a rough idea it wasn’t going to get played but we couldn’t be sure of it.“A few of the boys wanted to train but then we got the guidelines from the SFA to say we shouldn’t be training.#That’s an issue in football but not one in the rest of the world, I know.“In pre-season you know when the games are starting and how many weeks you have to prepare for the first game.“At the minute, we have no timescale at all which is dficult. Do you keep the players ticking over on their own or rest “The most important thing, though, is the health of everybody – as a club we are doing everything to look after our players and our staff, that’s paramount.“There’s not many times when I’ll say football isn’t important but it isn’t right now.”The Dundee players have been given inidual training programmes to work on at home but, with government advice to stay indoors as much as possible, it’s not easy for some.“As a club we have set up inidual programmes for the players but the trouble with that is a lot of the work is on treadmills or exercise bikes and not everyone has access to them,” added the Dens boss.“Otherwise you’re asking them to go out and do bits in the park and the advice is now not really to do that. story: It is far from business as usual but Mark Connolly insists Dundee United are doing everything they can to keep fit during lockdown.The coronavirus pandemic has put Scottish football into disarray, with the season suspended until further notice and players unable to train with their clubs.Like a large proportion of the population, however, footballers are working from home.For Irish defender Connolly and his United team-mates that means finding ways, however dficult it may be, to stay in peak physical condition should they get the chance to complete their season.“It has been strange, a once in a letime period we are in,” the -year-old said.“We finished last Tuesday and it has been over a week we have been off.“I have stayed at home with the we and the family and we have gone along with the medical and Government advice.“It is strange and dficult at times but it is something we all need to adhere to get back playing football, doing our jobs and getting back to le on a regular basis.“There is a dferent fitness for football and it is hard to replicate what you would do in terms of training.“The club has given us a programme, though, and we have a good group. Our boys are just ticking over.“We have a programme which we are due to start on Monday but it is tough because you are limited to what you can do.“We just need to keep ourselves ticking over because it will be quite a tough ask to get back to where we were beforewe are not training full-out every day.“I have been doing little bit in the garden.“It has been hard without weights and that so I have tried to improvise with stuff in the house to do dips and press-ups.“I bought one of those simulation spin bikes online the other day as well.“I needed to get something for inside the house. I think I was on every gym equipment website, both in the UK and abroad, and everywhere was a four-week wait.“I spoke to Gary Dempsey, our fitness coach, to try to rent a treadmill or spin bike.“Everything was sold out or rented out, so I couldn’t get anything.LEE WILKIE: It#s perfect time for Dundee United fans to look back with pride on incredible season" src"https:www.eveningtelegraph fp lee-wilkie-dundee-united-season-title embed # secretjFpUxvzSJ" data-secret"jFpUxvzSJ" width"" "" frameborder"" marginwidth"" margin"" scrolling"no"“Thankfully, I have managed to get this bike. It has a screen where you can do spin classes and use Google Maps.“I always enjoy doing Spin classes and it was always something I wanted to get further down the line anyway.“My we can use it and, hopefully, it will keep us fit and active.”Away from staying in shape, Connolly has been trying to keep himself entertained minus a le without live football.However, even switching on the TV right now isn’t brining any solace for the le-long Arsenal fan, after he was reminded of a painful derby defeat for the Gunners.“I was an Arsenal fan when I was younger, the Invincibles and all that,” he added.“Funnily enough, my dad took me and my sister to see them play at Old Trafford in  when we lost - to Manchester United.“I couldn’t believe how long ago it was –  years ago!”“They actually showed it on Sky Sports’ Monday Night Football as the main game because there is no football just now.“They even had Gary Neville and Jamie Carragher doing the analysis.“I remember we had to sit in with the Manchester United fans because somebody we knew from home was a season ticket holder and that is how we got to the game.“It wasn’t a great watch. It was horrible and I was surrounded by Manchester United fans, but at least Roy Keane scored that night!”

title: george cran coronavirus scottish football dundee united dundee fc
story: The coronavirus pandemic has hit society with a hammer blow but there is a silver lining to be gleaned from any dark cloud.Le as we knew it has completely changed.My le currently revolves around sitting in my flat coming up with stories to keep football fans entertained during these miserable times, walking my dog and avoiding my we when she tries to get me to do the odd jobs I’ve been putting off for years.I’m sure people reading this will be in a similar boat – day after day, it’s tough to keep going with good cheer.What the situation has given me is a chance to look back and think about all the good times I’ve had since moving to Dundee six years ago.Don’t worry, I’ll not bore you with all the soppy personal stuff but, on the football pitch, there have been some great moments to be witness to.Scottish football is rich with crazy stories on the field – I’m thinking of Wato Kuate totally losing the rag at Tannadice and a rampaging Sofien Moussa picking up two yellow cards in  minutes after coming on as a sub.As much as they were funny looking back, there are a few big wins I covered for both city clubs that stand out to me.Dark Blues might be surprised at my choice for the best performance I’ve seen in recent years.It was February  at Motherwell.Paul Hartley’s team were struggling after losing Greg Stewart, Kane Hemmings and Gary Harkins and that’s why it stands out so much.This was a team without creativity but, a week after beating Rangers, they smashed ’Well - and I can’t remember a better attacking performance I was witness to from a Dundee side.By half-time, a Zak Jules own goal had been added to by two from Marcus Haber and singles from Craig Wighton and Mark O’Hara.Before that game, Dundee’s top scorers in the XI were Haber and Paul McGowan on four which tells you how astonishing it was to see them rip Mark McGhee’s Motherwell to shreds.They would lose the next seven matches and Hartley his job. Looking back, that only makes the win all the more remarkable.For United, it was a far grander venue and harks back to the good old daysof regularly competing for big trophies.The  League Cup semi-final win over Aberdeen was my first experience of covering a big club game at Hampden. It was a great day with a huge Tangerine following rewarded with an amazing comeback victory thanks to Callum Morris and Nadir Ctci headers.Everyone has their own favourites and this stoppage is a great time to reminisce – hopefully, we won’t have to do that for too long.Uefa are due to meet via video conference today to thrash out some sort of plan for sorting how the current season ends.I’m glad to hear that’s because it’s pretty much certain their initial hopes to get club football completed by the end of June won’t be coming to fruition.August seems to be the consensus and it sounds fair enough.What I expect to come out of this virtual get-together is some sort of rational plan to sort out player contracts and technical issues like that.That’s what Uefa is there for. What I don’t expect them to do is grant the SPFL’s wishes by making tough decisions on how to end this season.I can’t help but think Neil Doncasterand SFA chief Ian Maxwellare desperate for Uefa to make a sweeping decision so they can avoid any sort of responsibility when people moan.My gut feeling is the European chiefs will have a plan to get the campaign finished in the autumn and roll straight into the new one. I would dearly love our set-up to be restructured to bigger leagues, however.After watching the  Scottish Cup Final on Sunday it made me think ‘where have all the cup finals gone’ It’s been five long years since Dundee United were last in a major cup final and  for Dundee. The end of my first season at the Tele saw the Tangerines in the Scottish Cup Final and then the League Cup showpiece a year later.It just shows how quickly things can fall apart – thankfully, both seem to be putting the pieces back together.To keep me amused I’ve been watching the Leeds United documentary on Amazon. I love these shows but think they are missing a trick not doing Scottish football – imagine all the bonkers stories they’d get up here!LEE WILKIE: I have sympathy for Neil Doncaster and Ian Maxwell but they need to grab the bull by the horns and show leadership" src"https:www.eveningtelegraph fp lee-wilkie-neil-doncaster-ian-maxwell embed # secretBXEngLa" data-secret"BXEngLa" width"" "" frameborder"" marginwidth"" margin"" scrolling"no"

title: lee wilkie neil doncaster ian maxwell
story: It’s been a long week of rumour and speculation since the last update we had from the SFA and the SPFL.What that radio silence hammers home most to me is a lack of leadership and decisiveness.Don’t get me wrong, I have sympathy for Ian Maxwell, Neil Doncaster  Co.This is a very complicated situation where you are unlikely to please everyone because so many doors could open up in dferent directions for clubs in terms of the current season and ongoing league structure.It melts your mind a bit when you start thinking about all the possibilities and how it could affect people but there needs to be a decision made soon.Uefa won’t do it for them, nor will Fa or English football, they need to grab the bull by the horns and show a bit of leadership.The resolution for all of this starts with them so it’s important they’re clear with their message.There’s no way they could possibly keep everybody happy but they must do something decisively and quite quickly to protect clubs and their incomes.I think most football people, myself included, would like to see the season played to a finish – eventhat is behind closed-doors.However, it’s beginning to look like we won’t see that happening at all given the current health guidelines from the UK and Scottish Governments pointing towards a longer lockdown being put in place across the country.August has been touted as the date for ato domestic football and, like I have said before, although it will be a long four months, it could be a good opportunity to restructure our gamedone correctly.It’s definitely an option and, depending on how it looks, I might even prefer that to closed-doors games.Reshuffling the leagues and increasing the number of teams will be refreshing and I think most fans would back that.Most of the clubs would be fairly happy, too, with no relegations across all four isions and promotion for the top two sides in the lower leagues.There may be some disputes about the tighter leagues and promotion play-offs but you’d like to think most would understand the extraordinary nature of the situation.Dundee would probably have been able to push Inverness right to the end and might feel a bit hard done by but it’s a really dficult one.I don’t envy the high heidyins but they’re paid to make these calls.The biggest thing that needs to be cleared up as soon as possible, for me, is the financial aspect of the shutdown.Clubs have been left in limbo by the powers that be for too long already.Many don’t have any income at all while there are still so many question marks about how they will access adequate monies from the SPFL and the SFA.It’s really important they decide what’s happening as soon as they can because clubs need to move on and plan for, what looks like, months ahead without any football.There’s so much work to do, it’s a bit of a head spinner.At this stage we’re not even taking into account the transfer window where, Dundee United in particular may be able to raise cash.I’m sure there will already have been plenty of enquiries about Lawrence Shankland.It’s probably a huge worry for a club like United. Of course, all clubs have dferent worries financially because they’re all in dferent situations.The least they deserve is clarity.Even in the summer it doesn’t take long for players to be itching to get back to football.The current situation with the coronavirus shutdown is a dferent kettle of fish entirely, though, and poses heightened mental health risks.For that reason, I was delighted to hear Tony Asghar say Dundee United are using a sport psychologist to help players stay positive.Clubs are far more equipped to deal with these things than when I started  years ago.My son Jack and I have been out on our bikes to try to break the boredom of lockdown this week.He’s been doing a lot of running as part of his training programme from Dundee but somehow I think I’ll stick to the pedals!

title: managing the coronavirus shut down has been my toughest test as dundee boss says james mcpake
story: The first year as a manager brings all sorts of challenges but James McPake admits dealing with the coronavirus from a football point of view takes the biscuit.The Dundee boss has had plenty to deal with during his debut campaign, including heavy derby defeats, issues with the law and a restless home support.Pressure has always been a major part of the role and it was ramped up during poor spells in the first half of the Championship campaign.McPake has always had more experienced heads to turn to for advice throughout his time in charge, whether assistant manager Jimmy Nicholl, technical director Gordon Strachan or someone outside the club.The current complete shutdown of Scottish football, however, is completely unprecedented.“This is one I can’t go to anyone for advice,” admits Dens gaffer McPake.“Nobody has faced anything like this. For loads of other stuff you can get advice, going on bad runs, good runs, heavy defeats, good times.“My first year has been a challenge. I always expected it would be a challenge but there was no way of expecting this to happen as manager of Dundee.“I’ve got kids not able to get to school like everyone up and down the country, people can’t go to work or getting laid off.“It is a challenge for me but nothing likeis going on in the rest of the world.”

title: on this day the victorian trio who became dundees first scotland stars
story: Today could have been the day where  years of hurt ended and Scotland finally secured its place at a major tournament again.Had they, as hoped, navigated a semi-final clash with Israel at Hampden last week, Scotland would have been in Norway or Serbia to play for a place in Euro .As it stands, none of that will happen tonight.Partly because it’s a hypothetical scenario but mainly because the coronavirus pandemic and shutdown of football has put paid to it.Those play-off clashes will now be played in June, at the earliest, with the finals themselves pushed back until next summer.Fortunately, today#s date also holds signicance historically for one of our city clubs.On March , , Dundee saw its first players earn Scots caps – three no less, in fact.Only an established club for less than a year, the Dark Blues had goalkeeper Francis Barrett, captain William Longair and winger Sandy Keillor all start for the national team against Ireland.Taking place at Cltonville’s Solitude ground in Belfast, nearly , spectators packed in as Scotland ran out - winners in a British International Championship match thanks to a Samuel Torrans own goal and John Taylor strike.Barret would go on to win just the one more cap for his country but wore the dark blue of Dundee with distinction  times.Born in Dundee on August ,  to Irish parents, he began his career at Dundee Harp – a club formed to try to emulate Celtic and Hibernian in providing a sporting focus for the catholic community in Scotland’s major cities.They had harboured ambitions to be the city’s top side before East End and Our Boys formed Dundee Football Club as we know it today in .In December of its first season, looking to bolster their back line, the Dee swooped for Harp keeper, Barrett.Their problems were clear for all to see as he became the fth goalkeeper the ‘Ten-bobbers’ used that season when he made his debut against Hearts on December .Barret remained at the club until the summer of  before signing for Newton Heath, now Manchester United, and went on to play against Dundee in a friendly – one of his  appearances for the Red Devils.Spells at New Brighton Tower, Manchester City and Aberdeen followed, before Barrett began to suffer from ill health, eventually passing away aged just  in .Hall of Fame inductee Longair, known as “Plum”, was a terric servant to Dundee – stretching back to the days of East End, for whom he signed in .The match against Ireland was Plum’s only cap in a career which also stopped in at Newton Heath as well as Sunderland, Burnley and Brighton United.Born in Dundee in , the centre-half would make  appearances for the Dee, scoring four goals and captaining the club in its first-ever fixture against Rangers in  – a - draw at West Craigie Park.Skippering the side is something Longair would do multiple times in his four spells until his retirement from playing in .He would go on to be the club’s trainer for their  Scottish Cup success and later become groundsman before his sad death aged just  in .It is estimated , people lined the streets for his funeral, showing the high regard in which the Dundonian public held him.Keillor was not only one of the first Dundee players to play for Scotland but also the first to score.Picking up four caps in total, the attacking talent also made  appearances for the Dark Blues, scoring  goals.Born in Dundee on October , , Keillor was brought up in Montrose and began his career with the Links Park side in .He joined the newly-formed Dundee FC in  with two Scotland caps already under his belt and, like Longair, played in the club’s first-ever match against Rangers.The outside-left was seen as a complete footballer with The Courier writing at the time that “he had a knack of rising to the big occasion”.And he did just that when Scotland hosted Wales at Dundee’s Carolina Port in , with Keillor getting his goal in a - win for the Scots.Keillor was awarded a testimonial against Celtic in , with , supporters turning up.He remained with the club until , playing at the new Dens Park alongside Longair, before ing to Montrose and hanging up his boots in . He died aged  in .
